tips.title: Stay Hydrated
tips.content: Drink at least 8-10 glasses of water daily. Proper hydration supports amniotic fluid levels and helps prevent constipation.

tips.title: Take Your Prenatal Vitamins
tips.content: Prenatal vitamins with folic acid are essential for your baby's neural tube development. Take them at the same time each day.

tips.title: Sleep on Your Side
tips.content: After 20 weeks, sleeping on your left side improves blood flow to your baby. Use pillows for support.

tips.title: Count Those Kicks
tips.content: Starting at 28 weeks, monitor your baby's movements. You should feel at least 10 movements within 2 hours.

tips.title: Pelvic Floor Exercises
tips.content: Kegel exercises strengthen your pelvic floor muscles, helping with labor and postpartum recovery. Do them daily!

tips.title: Eat Small, Frequent Meals
tips.content: Eating 5-6 small meals instead of 3 large ones can help with nausea and heartburn.

tips.title: Gentle Stretching
tips.content: Light stretching can help relieve back pain and muscle tension. Focus on your lower back and hips.

tips.title: Baby Can Hear You
tips.content: Around 18 weeks, your baby starts hearing! Talk, sing, or play music for your little one.

tips.title: Practice Breathing
tips.content: Deep breathing exercises help reduce stress and will be useful during labor. Practice daily for a few minutes.

tips.title: Iron-Rich Foods
tips.content: Include iron-rich foods like spinach, lean meat, and beans to prevent anemia and support your growing baby.

tips.title: Create Your Birth Plan
tips.content: Start thinking about your birth preferences. Discuss pain management options and who you want present.

tips.title: Rest When You're Tired
tips.content: Growing a baby is hard work! Listen to your body and rest when needed. Short naps can be very beneficial.

tips.title: Pack Your Hospital Bag
tips.content: Around 36 weeks, prepare your hospital bag with essentials for you and baby. Don't forget phone chargers!

tips.title: Moisturize Your Skin
tips.content: Keep your belly, hips, and breasts moisturized to help with stretching skin and reduce itchiness.

tips.title: Prenatal Classes
tips.content: Consider signing up for prenatal or birthing classes. They help prepare you and your partner for labor.

tips.title: First Trimester Fatigue
tips.content: Feeling exhausted is normal in the first trimester. Your body is working hard. This usually improves by week 12.

tips.title: Managing Morning Sickness
tips.content: Try eating crackers before getting out of bed, avoid strong smells, and eat ginger to help with nausea.

tips.title: Get Enough Calcium
tips.content: Your baby needs calcium for bone development. Include dairy products, fortified foods, or supplements.

tips.title: Don't Skip Dental Care
tips.content: Pregnancy hormones can affect your gums. Continue regular dental checkups and maintain good oral hygiene.

tips.title: Omega-3 Fatty Acids
tips.content: Omega-3s support your baby's brain development. Safe sources include salmon, sardines, and DHA supplements.

tips.title: Daily Walking
tips.content: A 30-minute daily walk improves circulation, boosts mood, and helps maintain a healthy weight.

tips.title: Baby's Movements May Change
tips.content: As baby grows bigger, movements may feel different but should still be regular. Contact your provider if concerned.

tips.title: Limit Caffeine
tips.content: Keep caffeine under 200mg daily (about one 12oz coffee). Too much may affect your baby's growth.

tips.title: Build Your Support System
tips.content: Connect with other expecting parents, family, or friends. Having support makes the journey easier.

tips.title: Third Trimester Begins
tips.content: Welcome to the final stretch! Focus on rest, preparation, and enjoying these last weeks of pregnancy.
